io.deepstream

Class Record

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.deepstream.Record

  • public class Record
extends java.lang.Object
    This class represents a single record - an observable dataset returned by RecordHandler.getRecord(String)

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      Record addRecordEventsListener(RecordEventsListener recordEventsListener)
      Adds a Listener that will notify you if a Discard, Delete or Error event occurs
      Record delete()
      Delete the record.
      Record discard()
      Discard the record.
      com.google.gson.JsonElement get()
      Gets the entire record data and should always return a JsonObject, except when using a List, but then you should always be using it via List.getEntries() ;)
      com.google.gson.JsonElement get(java.lang.String path)
      Gets the value at the path indicated.

      For example, if the record data is:
      { "name": "Yasser", pets: [ { type: "Dog", "name": "Whiskey", age: 3} ]}

      We can do:
      get( "name" ) -> JsonElement.getAsString()
      get( "pets[0]" ) -> JsonElement.getAsJsonObject()
      get( "pets[0].age") -> JsonElement.getAsInt()
      boolean isDestroyed()
      Return whether the record data has been destroyed.
      boolean isReady()
      Return whether the record data has been loaded from the server
      java.lang.String name()
      Return the record name
      Record removeRecordEventsListener(RecordEventsListener recordEventsListener)
      Remove listener added via addRecordEventsListener(RecordEventsListener)
      Record set(java.lang.Object value)
      Set the value for the entire record
      Make sure that the Object passed in can be serialised to a JsonElement, otherwise it will throw a IllegalStateException.
      Record set(java.lang.String path, java.lang.Object value)
      Set the value for a specific path in your Record data.
      Make sure that the Object passed in can be serialised to a JsonElement, otherwise it will throw a IllegalStateException.
      The best way to guarantee this is by setting Json friendly objects, such as Map.
      If you path is not null, you can pass in primitives as long as the path is not null, which is the equivalent of calling set(Object).
      Record setMergeStrategy(MergeStrategy mergeStrategy)
      Set a merge strategy that comes with deepstream.
      Record setMergeStrategy(RecordMergeStrategy mergeStrategy)
      Set a custom merge strategy for this record
      Record subscribe(RecordChangedCallback recordChangedCallback)
      Notifies the user whenever anything inside the Record has changed.
      Record subscribe(RecordChangedCallback recordChangedCallback, boolean triggerNow)
      Notifies the user whenever anything inside the Record has changed, and triggers the listener immediately.
      Record subscribe(java.lang.String path, RecordChangedCallback recordChangedCallback)
      Notifies the user whenever anything under the path provided has changed.
      Record subscribe(java.lang.String path, RecordChangedCallback recordChangedCallback, boolean triggerNow)
      Subscribe to record changes.
      If a path is provided, updates will be based on everything in or under it.
      If trigger now is true, the listener will be immediately fired with the current value.
      Record unsubscribe(RecordChangedCallback recordChangedCallback)
      Remove the listener added via subscribe(RecordChangedCallback, boolean)
      Record unsubscribe(java.lang.String path, RecordChangedCallback recordChangedCallback)
      Remove the listener added via subscribe(String,RecordChangedCallback, boolean)
      int version()
      Return the record version.

    • Method Detail

      • isReady

        public boolean isReady()
        Return whether the record data has been loaded from the server
        Returns:
        true if record has been loaded

      • isDestroyed

        public boolean isDestroyed()
        Return whether the record data has been destroyed. If true and you need to use the method create it again via RecordHandler.getRecord(String)
        Returns:
        true if record has been destroyed

      • version

        public int version()
        Return the record version. This is solely used within a RecordMergeStrategy.
        Returns:
        -1 if not loaded, otherwise the local version number

      • name

        public java.lang.String name()
        Return the record name
        Returns:
        The record name

        Parameters:

        Returns:

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        The record

      • setMergeStrategy

        public Record setMergeStrategy(MergeStrategy mergeStrategy)
        Set a merge strategy that comes with deepstream. These are currently LOCAL_WINS and REMOTE_WINS
        Parameters:
        mergeStrategy - The name of the built in merge strategy to use
        Returns:
        The record

      • setMergeStrategy

        public Record setMergeStrategy(RecordMergeStrategy mergeStrategy)
        Set a custom merge strategy for this record
        Parameters:
        mergeStrategy - The custom merge strategy to use
        Returns:
        The record

      • get

        public com.google.gson.JsonElement get(java.lang.String path)
        Gets the value at the path indicated.

        For example, if the record data is:
        { "name": "Yasser", pets: [ { type: "Dog", "name": "Whiskey", age: 3} ]}

        We can do:
        get( "name" ) -> JsonElement.getAsString()
        get( "pets[0]" ) -> JsonElement.getAsJsonObject()
        get( "pets[0].age") -> JsonElement.getAsInt()
        Returns:
        The record data as a JsonElement

      • get

        public com.google.gson.JsonElement get()
        Gets the entire record data and should always return a JsonObject, except when using a List, but then you should always be using it via List.getEntries() ;)
        Returns:
        The record data as a json element
        See Also:
        get(String)

      • set

        public Record set(java.lang.Object value)
           throws DeepstreamRecordDestroyedException
        Set the value for the entire record
        Make sure that the Object passed in can be serialised to a JsonElement, otherwise it will throw a IllegalStateException. Best way to guarantee this is by setting Json friendly objects, such as Map. Since this is a root the object should also not be a primitive.
        Throws:
        DeepstreamRecordDestroyedException
        See Also:
        set(String, Object)

      • set

        public Record set(java.lang.String path,
         java.lang.Object value)
           throws DeepstreamRecordDestroyedException
        Set the value for a specific path in your Record data.
        Make sure that the Object passed in can be serialised to a JsonElement, otherwise it will throw a IllegalStateException.
        The best way to guarantee this is by setting Json friendly objects, such as Map.
        If you path is not null, you can pass in primitives as long as the path is not null, which is the equivalent of calling set(Object).
        Parameters:
        path - The path with the JsonElement at which to set the value
        value - The value to set
        Returns:
        The record
        Throws:
        DeepstreamRecordDestroyedException - Thrown if the record has been destroyed and can't perform more actions

      • subscribe

        public Record subscribe(java.lang.String path,
               RecordChangedCallback recordChangedCallback)
                 throws DeepstreamRecordDestroyedException
        Notifies the user whenever anything under the path provided has changed.
        Throws:
        DeepstreamRecordDestroyedException
        See Also:
        subscribe(String, RecordChangedCallback, boolean)

      • subscribe

        public Record subscribe(RecordChangedCallback recordChangedCallback)
                 throws DeepstreamRecordDestroyedException
        Notifies the user whenever anything inside the Record has changed.
        Throws:
        DeepstreamRecordDestroyedException
        See Also:
        subscribe(String, RecordChangedCallback, boolean)

      • subscribe

        public Record subscribe(RecordChangedCallback recordChangedCallback,
               boolean triggerNow)
                 throws DeepstreamRecordDestroyedException
        Notifies the user whenever anything inside the Record has changed, and triggers the listener immediately.
        Throws:
        DeepstreamRecordDestroyedException
        See Also:
        subscribe(String, RecordChangedCallback, boolean)

      • subscribe

        public Record subscribe(java.lang.String path,
               RecordChangedCallback recordChangedCallback,
               boolean triggerNow)
                 throws DeepstreamRecordDestroyedException
        Subscribe to record changes.
        If a path is provided, updates will be based on everything in or under it.
        If trigger now is true, the listener will be immediately fired with the current value.
        Parameters:
        path - The path to listen to
        recordChangedCallback - The listener to add
        triggerNow - Whether to immediately trigger the listener with the current value
        Returns:
        The record
        Throws:
        DeepstreamRecordDestroyedException - Thrown if the record has been destroyed and can't perform more actions

      • unsubscribe

        public Record unsubscribe(RecordChangedCallback recordChangedCallback)
                   throws DeepstreamRecordDestroyedException
        Remove the listener added via subscribe(RecordChangedCallback, boolean)
        Throws:
        DeepstreamRecordDestroyedException
        See Also:
        unsubscribe(String, RecordChangedCallback)

      • unsubscribe

        public Record unsubscribe(java.lang.String path,
                 RecordChangedCallback recordChangedCallback)
                   throws DeepstreamRecordDestroyedException
        Remove the listener added via subscribe(String,RecordChangedCallback, boolean)
        Parameters:
        path - The path to unsubscribe from
        recordChangedCallback - The listener to remove
        Returns:
        The record
        Throws:
        DeepstreamRecordDestroyedException - Thrown if the record has been destroyed and can't perform more actions

      • discard

        public Record discard()
               throws DeepstreamRecordDestroyedException
        Discard the record. This should be called whenever you are done with the record retrieved by RecordHandler.getRecord(String). This does not guarantee that your subscriptions have been unsubscribed, so make sure to do that first!
        If all usages of the same record have been discarded, the record will no longer be updated from the server and any further usages will require the record to be retrieved again via RecordHandler.getRecord(String)
        Once the record is successfully discard, you can be notified via RecordEventsListener.onRecordDiscarded(String)
        Returns:
        The record
        Throws:
        DeepstreamRecordDestroyedException - Thrown if the record has been destroyed and can't perform more actions

      • delete

        public Record delete()
              throws DeepstreamRecordDestroyedException
        Delete the record. This is called when you want to remove the record entirely from deepstream, deleting it from storage and cache and telling all other users that it has been deleted. This in turn will force all clients to discard the record.
        Once the record is successfully deleted, you can be notified via RecordEventsListener.onRecordDeleted(String) (String)}
        Returns:
        The record
        Throws:
        DeepstreamRecordDestroyedException - Thrown if the record has been destroyed and can't perform more actions
